Title: A space curve is planar if and only if its torsion is everywhere 0
Content:
Can someone please explain this proof to me. I know that a circle is planar and has nonzero constant curvature, so this must be an exception, but I am a little lost on the proof. 
Thanks!
AcceptedAnswer:
A circle is indeed planar, and has constant nonzero curvature, but the torsion of a circle is zero; it's not an exception. Having said this, let $\gamma(s)$ be a regular planar curve in $\Bbb R^3$ parametrized by arc length, say $\gamma:I 	o \Bbb R^3$ , where $I \subset \Bbb R$ is an open interval. $\gamma(s)$ regular means $\dot{\gamma}(s) = \dfrac{d\gamma(s)}{ds} 
e 0 	ag{1}$ for any $s \in I$ . If $P \subset \Bbb R^3$ is any plane passing through the point $\vec p_0 \in \Bbb R^3$ , then the points $\vec r = (x, y, z) \in P$ satisfy an equation of the form $(\vec r - \vec p_0) \cdot \vec n = 0, 	ag{2}$ where $\vec n$ is the unit normal vector to $P$ ; that $P$ may be so described is well-known, and will be taken so here without further demonstration. If we insert $\gamma(s) = (\gamma_x(s), \gamma_y(s), \gamma_z(s))$ into (2), we see that $(\gamma(s) - \vec p_0) \cdot \vec n = 0, 	ag{3}$ and differentiating (3) we obtain $\dot \gamma(s) \cdot \vec n = 0. 	ag{4}$ We next recall that $\dot \gamma(s) = \vec T(s), 	ag{5}$ where $\vec T(s)$ is the unit tangent vector to $\gamma(s)$ , $\vec T(s) = \dot \gamma(s)$ (since $s$ is arc-length); then by (4) $\vec T(s) \cdot \vec n = 0; 	ag{6}$ furthermore, by the Frenet-Serret equation $\dot {\vec T}(s) = \kappa \vec N(s), 	ag{7}$ applied to (6) we have $\kappa(s) \vec N(s) \cdot \vec n = \dot {\vec T}(s) \cdot \vec n = 0; 	ag{8}$ from (8) we see that, as long as $\kappa(s) 
e 0$ , that is, as long as $\vec N(s)$ may be defined , we have $\vec N(s) \cdot \vec n = 0 	ag{9}$ holding as well as (6); thus both $\vec T(s)$ and $\vec N(s)$ are normal to $\vec n$ as long as they are defined. Now $T(s)$ and $N(s)$ form an orthonormal system; that is $\Vert \vec T(s) \Vert = \Vert \vec N(s) \Vert = 1$ and $\vec T(s) \cdot \vec N(s) = 0$ , and since the unit binormal vector along $\gamma(s)$ , $\vec B(s) = \vec T(s) 	imes \vec N(s)$ also satisifies $\vec B(s) \cdot \vec T(s) = (\vec T(s) 	imes \vec N(s)) \cdot \vec T(s) = 0, 	ag{10}$ $\vec B(s) \cdot \vec N(s) = (\vec T(s) 	imes \vec N(s)) \cdot \vec N(s) = 0, 	ag{11}$ $\vec B(s) \cdot \vec B(s) = 1, 	ag{12}$ we may conclude from the continuity of $\vec B(s)$ that $\vec B(s) = \pm \vec n, 	ag{13}$ a constant ; thus from $\dot {\vec B}(s) = -	au(s) \vec N(s), 	ag{14}$ the Frenet-Serret equation for $\dot {\vec B}(s)$ , we may infer that $	au(s) \vec N(s) = 0 \Rightarrow 	au(s) = 0, 	ag{15}$ since $\vec N(s) 
e 0$ wherever it is defined; we have shown that the torsion $	au(s)$ of any plane curve $\gamma(s)$ vanishes. Of course, there are a couple of caveats in the above argument, most notably the assumptions of regularity (so that $\vec T(s)$ exists), and non-vanishing curvature (so that $\vec N(s)$ exists); but I think these can be covered pretty easily; I'll defer the discussion until after we have handled the "if" direction of the assertion's logic. So suppose $	au(s) = 0$ ; that is, that $\gamma(s)$ is a regular curve in $\Bbb R^3$ with vanishing torsion. Then $\vec B(s)$ must be constant along $\gamma(s)$ , by (14); choosing $s_0 \in I$ we have $\vec B(s_0) = \vec B(s)$ for all $s \in I$ ; thus by (10)-(11) $\vec T(s)$ and $\vec N(s)$ both belong to the subspace $V \subset \Bbb R^3$ with $\vec B(s_0)  ot V$ ; indeed, we may take this subspace to be spanned by $\vec T(s_0)$ , $\vec N(s_0)$ , since they form an orthonormal pair in $V$ ; $V = 	ext{span} \{ \vec T(s_0), \vec N(s_0) \}$ . This being the case, we may write $\dot {\gamma}(s) = \vec T(s) = \langle \vec T(s), \vec T(s_0) angle \vec T(s_0) + \langle \vec T(s), \vec N(s_0) angle \vec N(s_0); 	ag{16}$ upon integrating (16) we find $\gamma(s) - \gamma(s_0) = \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \dot {\gamma}(u) du = \int_{s_0}^s \vec T(u) du$ $= \left (\displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \langle \vec T(u), \vec T(s_0) angle du ight ) \vec T(s_0) + \left (\displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \langle \vec T(u), \vec N(s_0) angle du ight ) \vec N(s_0), 	ag{17}$ which implies that $(\gamma(s) - \gamma(s_0)) \cdot \vec B(s_0)$ $ =(\int_{s_0}^s \langle \vec T(u), \vec T(s_0) angle du) \langle \vec T(s_0), \vec B(s_0) angle$ $+ (\int_{s_0}^s \langle \vec T(u), \vec N(s_0) angle du) \langle \vec N(s_0), \vec B(s_0) angle = 0 	ag{18}$ for all $s \in I$ ; but the equation of the plane normal to $\vec B(s_0)$ passing through the point $\gamma(s_0)$ is in fact $(\vec r - \gamma(s_0)) \cdot \vec B(s_0) = 0, 	ag{19}$ where $\vec r = (x, y, z)$ . Thus $\gamma(s)$ lies in this plane. QED. We can actually take things a step further and present concise formulas for $\vec T(s)$ and $\vec N(s)$ in terms of $\displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u)du$ as follows: When $	au(s) = 0$ , the Frenet-Serret equations become $\dot{\vec T}(s) = \kappa(s) \vec N(s), 	ag{20}$ $\dot{\vec N}(s) = -\kappa(s) \vec T(s), 	ag{21}$ and $\dot {\vec B}(s) = 0. 	ag{22}$ (22) implies $B(s)$ is constant; inspecting (20)-(21) reveals they may be written in combined form by introducing the six-dimensional column vector $\vec \Theta(s)$ : $\vec \Theta(s) = (\vec T(s), \vec N(s))^T, 	ag{23}$ so that $\dot {\vec \Theta}(s) = (\dot {\vec T}(s), \dot {\vec N}(s))^T; 	ag{24}$ with this convention, (20)-(21) may be written $\dot {\vec {\Theta}}(s) =  egin{bmatrix} 0 & \kappa(s)I_3 \ -\kappa(s)I_3 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \vec {\Theta}(s) = \kappa(s) J \vec{\Theta}(s), 	ag{25}$ where $I_3$ is the $3 	imes 3$ identity matrix and $J =  egin{bmatrix} 0 & I_3 \ -I_3 & 0 \end{bmatrix}; 	ag{26}$ here it is understood that $J$ is presented in the from of $3 	imes 3$ blocks.  It is easy to see that $J^2 =  egin{bmatrix} 0 & I_3 \ -I_3 & 0 \end{bmatrix} egin{bmatrix} 0 & I_3 \ -I_3 & 0 \end{bmatrix} =  egin{bmatrix} -I_3 & 0 \ 0 & -I_3 \end{bmatrix} = -I_6, 	ag{27}$ $I_6$ being the $6 	imes 6$ identity matrix.  Careful scrutiny of (25) suggests that $\vec \Theta(s) = \exp \left (\left ( \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight ) J ight ) \vec \Theta(s_0) 	ag{28}$ might be its unique solution taking the value $\vec \Theta(s_0)$ at $s = s_0$ ; indeed, we may differentiate (28) with respect to $s$ to obtain $\dot {\vec \Theta}(s) = \dfrac{d}{ds}\left (\displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u)du ight )J\exp \left (\left ( \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight ) J ight ) \vec \Theta(s_0) = \kappa(s) J \vec \Theta(s), 	ag{29}$ showing that (28) satisfies (25); furthermore (28) is consistent with the initial condition at $s = s_0$ ; $\vec \Theta (s_0) =  \exp \left (\left ( \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^{s_0} \kappa(u) du ight ) J ight ) \vec \Theta(s_0) = e^{0J} \vec \Theta(s_0) = \vec \Theta(s_0). 	ag{30}$ It is worth pointing out that the reason (28) works as a solution is basically that the $s$ -derivative of the matrix $\exp \left (\left ( \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight ) J ight )$ follows the scalar pattern $\dfrac{d}{ds}e^{u(s)} = \dfrac{du(s)}{ds}e^{u(s)}, 	ag{31}$ viz. $\dfrac{d}{ds}\exp \left (\left ( \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight ) J ight ) = \dfrac{d}{ds}\left (\displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight)J\exp \left (\left ( \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight ) J ight )$ $= \kappa(s)J\exp \left (\left ( \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight ) J ight ). 	ag{32}$ (32) applies by virtue of the fact that $\left ( \displaystyle\int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight)J$ and its derivative $\kappa(s) J$ commute with one another, being scalar function multiples of the same matrix $J$ ; for general matrix functions $A(s)$ , it is not true that $A'(s)A(s) = A(s)A'(s)$ , and the evaluation of $(d/ds)A(s)$ becomes much more complicated; we do not in general have $\dfrac{d}{ds}e^{A(s)} = \dfrac{A(s)}{ds}e^{A(s)} 	ag{33}$ in parallel with the scalar formula (31); the interested reader may consult my answer to this question (especially the material surrounding equations (15)-(20)) for a more detailed discussion.  However, under the special circumstances that $A(s) = f(s)B$ for a constant matrix $B$ , then $A'(s) = f'(s)B$ and $A(s)A'(s) = f(s)f'(s)B^2 = A'(s)A(s)$ ; $A(s)$ and its derivative always commute in this special case, which is what we have here.  (32) applies and thus we have that (28) solves (25). We examine the matrix $\exp \left (\left ( \displaystyle \int_{s_0}^s \kappa(u) du ight ) J ight )$ occurring in (28) with an eye to determining its structure, and the structure of the solutions to (25).  That $J^2 = - I_6$ has been noted.  Thus we have $J^2 = -I_6; \; \; J^3 = J^2J = -J; \;\;$ $J^4 = J^3J= -J^2 = I_6; \; \; J^5 = (J^4)J = I_6J = J, 	ag{34}$ and in general, $J^{4n + p} = J^{4n}J^p = (J^4)^nJ^p = (I_6)^n J^p = J^p, 	ag{35}$ which shows that all cases of $J^m$ , $m \in \Bbb Z$ , are in fact covered by (34), i.e. for $0 \le p \le 3$ .
